title: Everything you need to know about the U.N. General Assembly
text:
Everything you need to know about the U.N. General Assembly Presented by S&P Global

WELCOME TO POLITICO'S FIRST-EVER UNITED NATIONS PLAYBOOK.

Why are we doing this? The United Nations General Assembly, from the depths of the Cold War to today, is simply the world’s biggest diplomatic platform. Each year, representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in New York to press their agendas, network and gossip.

I’ll be at U.N. headquarters in Turtle Bay and leapfrogging through a maze of side events to guide you through a jam-packed week, along with my colleagues from the POLITICO mothership in Washington and our European office in Brussels. Send tips, spotteds and gripes to rheath@politico.com.

The 2019 meeting comes at a time of North Korean missile launches, U.S.-Iran tensions, Kashmir flare-ups, Hong Kong protests and a breakdown in Afghan peace talks. Nearly everyone is talking climate action — with the notable exception of the U.S. — but their words aren’t meeting their Paris climate agreement commitments, prompting a global “climate strike” in 4,500 cities and towns taking place today.

The U.K. is Brexiting, Russia is disrupting, and China’s strategic rise marches on. It’s a more competitive form of multilateralism than the old days of America vs. the Soviets, that’s for sure — and it’s only getting more complicated.

A Little Context

To its critics, the U.N. General Assembly is a pointless gabfest and an excuse for the wives of dictators to enjoy some 5th Avenue shopping. A more accurate picture is that UNGA is the most important event where not much gets decided. It’s the political equivalent of “Seinfeld.”

But don’t let the boring speeches by leaders and woke rhetoric fool you. Yes, UNGA lacks the deals of Davos, the military brass of security summits and the silicon glitz of hedge fund and tech retreats. But it’s geopolitics and policy by all means possible, in the greatest city on Earth.

IT’S THE CIVIL SOCIETY, STUPID: The business getting done here is that of long-term thinking and networking, most of it away from the headlines.

That is born of necessity. Official U.N. channels are almost destined to gum up. The Security Council operates by veto; the General Assembly accords Tuvalu and the United States equal voting power; and the U.N. bureaucracy can’t raise any of its own funds, leaving it reliant on a few generous donor governments and a notoriously messed-up staffing system.

In recent years, the world’s activist and donor classes have taken it upon themselves to rewire the organization. They’ve been joined by local and regional governments in changing the U.N. from the outside. What’s really happening is that these external pressures on the U.N. are the vanguard of a revolution in diplomacy.

Diplomacy is no longer only a government-to-government affair. Leaders and ambassadors matter — they’re the reason everyone is gathered in New York — but the main actors in this brave new world think only a fool would leave it to them to address a challenge like climate change.

HACKING THE U.N.: Over 20 years and two rounds of U.N.-mandated global development goals, NGOs (including plenty of large corporations and banks) have begun delivering a dizzying array of partnerships — with, adjacent to, and sometimes in spite of — official U.N. systems. They aim to do everything from save a million children from cancer to getting everyone a toilet. They want to restore the climate to its pre-industrial balance and stop pandemics. This year will also be the most youthful UNGA ever — thanks to two “climate strikes” led by teenagers that will bookend the week. If it looks messy and chaotic, that’s because it is.

NAVIGATING THE MAZE: UNGA week is so decentralized it’s hard to know where to start. That’s because UNGA is where the world, not just the 1 percent, comes to lobby, network and protest.

While first-timers at the U.N. likely see only a maze of rapporteurs and envoys and acronyms, and reporters may be tempted to focus on only what the national leaders do and say on the treadmill of five-minute speeches in front of other leaders, the real action is elsewhere.

We’re here to help: More than 300 events are taking place over the coming week, but don’t worry — POLITICO’s got you covered. Read on for traffic and coffee tips, event listing and insights from behind the curtains at ambassadors’ residences across the Big Apple.

Official Narratives vs. Corridor Talk

Jeffrey Feltman, a former chief foreign policy adviser to current U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres and his predecessor Ban Ki-moon, now at the Brookings Institution, says, “I’m always struck by the official discrepancy between the high-level agenda and what everyone talks about in the corridors.” This year he expects climate will be prominent both on and off official podiums, but other corridor talk “will be about Iran, energy supplies and trade wars. The U.S. is in the middle of all three of those.”

There’s a “discrepancy” between Trump and Barack Obama and how they use the week, Feltman noted. Obama would pick an issue each year to “force an agenda on the entire international community,” he said, but there’s no clear sense of what the Trump administration will push this year. It will be prominent, but not by design.

Storylines to Watch for This Week

U.S. v. World: That’s a given as a climate narrative, and many countries will push it as a trade narrative as well. With the Trump administration looking to overhaul its development and U.N. funding approach, the world’s list of grievances will be longer than usual.

Will Trump and Rouhani meet? Almost certainly not. The U.S. is open to meeting with the Iranian leader, but will not make concessions to secure such talks, and the recent attacks in Saudi Arabia all but foreclosed the possibility.

France as global mediator: Emmanuel Macron will spend the week pushing allies to adopt a new type of multilateralism with France as the new global mediator. Case in point: While President Trump won’t meet with the Iranians, Macron will likely meet with both and ferry ideas back and forth. The goal: deescalation, while accepting that France can’t force those who don’t want to negotiate to negotiate. Macron is seizing the opportunity of Boris Johnson being distracted with Brexit, Angela Merkel being in her twilight and Justin Trudeau flailing in scandal. His top issues will be climate, Iran and Libya.

Brexit: The U.K. and Europe are in the middle of a full-blown meltdown in relations, with British PM Boris Johnson trying to make good on his promise to leave the EU. We’ll give you a daily Boris Brief, with tips on what to care and not care about in the Brexit circus.

Is democracy failing? With strongmen leaders set to dominate the first day of leaders’ speeches on Tuesday, it’s worth pondering whether democracy’s golden age is over. As one recent POLITICO Magazine piece put it: “In 1945, according to one survey, there were just 12 democracies in the entire world. By the end of the century there were 87. But then came the great reversal.”

Leader Watch

WHO’S IN AND WHO’S OUT: The list of no-shows is substantial this year. Don’t expect to see Russian President Vladimir Putin, China’s President Xi Jinping, Canada’s Trudeau (election), Israel’s Benjamin Netanyahu, Iran’s Hassan Rouhani or North Korea’s Kim Jong-un. (PassBlue has been keeping tabs.)

One country going big is Ireland. Despite the shadow of Brexit hanging over the Emerald Isle, they’re sending their prime minister, president and foreign minister to lobby for a non-permanent seat on the U.N. Security Council. That’s an attempt to counterbalance any negative effects of Brexit, and to catch Canada napping as the country sends only a thin delegation while the rest of the heavy-hitters are campaigning to save their jobs in the federal election. Note to Justin Trudeau: Brownface is an especially bad look at the United Nations.

WHERE’S TRUMP? Today he’s meeting Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison before a state dinner in honor of the Australians tonight at the White House. Trump heads to Houston on Sunday for a rally with Indian PM Narendra Modi. When Trump hits New York next week (he speaks to the General Assembly Tuesday morning), his meetings are expected to include Boris Johnson and Moon Jae-in, the South Korean president. One of Trump’s side engagements will be a campaign fundraising dinner charging a whopping $250,000 per couple, CBS reported.

CRAFT LIKE NO ONE’S WATCHING: After months with no U.S. ambassador in Turtle Bay, Kelly Craft is now finally in place, with a difficult journey ahead of her. Beyond mounting global frustration with her boss, Craft also has to deal with people dismissing her position. The job no longer has Cabinet rank, and with Craft being the fourth woman in a row to hold the post, the corridor chatter among some diplomatic dinosaurs is that the women can keep the job.

What’s Craft’s strategy? Lay low and drink tea. Craft is out greasing the wheels of U.S. diplomacy in a series of what could end up being more than 100 meet-and-greet sessions with fellow ambassadors to the U.N. Don’t underestimate that approach: The previous U.S. ambassador, Nikki Haley, was well-briefed but reputed to rub her colleagues the wrong way. Craft’s plan is to avoid that by sticking to the people skills she knows best, according to her team.

WHO RUNS THE U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY ANYWAY? Poverty, education and inclusion top the priority list of Nigeria’s U.N. envoy, Tijjani Muhammad-Bande, who is in charge of the General Assembly this year. Check out the U.N. News interview.

— Fun fact: China offered to fund Muhammad-Bande’s office for the next year, according to Nigeria's minister of foreign affairs, Geoffrey Onyeama.

CLIMATE IS THE INESCAPABLE ISSUE: Whether leaders care to address it or not, everyone else, from the U.N. bureaucracy to the world’s biggest banks to angry students, are forcing the issue. Jeff Bezos is the latest to join the mix. You know climate action is mainstream when Mike Bloomberg and some of the world’s largest institutions across the investment chain — Allianz Global Investors, AXA, Enel, Goldman Sachs, Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund, HSBC, and Macquarie — have urged peers to accelerate low-carbon investments via a Climate Finance Leadership Initiative.

Pre-Game Listening

Inside Russia’s U.N. mission: The U.N.-Scripted podcast, by Stephanie Fillion and Kacie Candela, spoke to Russia’s first deputy permanent representative (No. 2) Dmitry Polyanskiy.

German perspective: Berlin’s ambassador to the U.N., Christoph Heusgen, has a video Q&A on YouTube, discussing Germany’s role in the Security Council and its priorities for the UNGA.

U.N. insiders: Before POLITICO’s own U.N. podcast runs next week, I recommend Mark Leon Goldberg’s Global Dispatches as a way to get up to speed. Two recent episodes include an interview with U.N. Secretary General Antonio Guterres, and another with Margaret Besheer, U.N. correspondent for Voice of America, and Richard Gowan, U.N. director for the International Crisis Group.

Catching Our Eye

Conflict in perspective: UNICEF laid out 3,758 school backpacks on a New York park lawn, representing the number of child deaths in conflict over the past year.

UNGA fashion: Ralph Lauren has a sale on its U.N.-inspired tote bag — yours for just $39.99.

DataPoints of the Day

PANDEMIC + MISINFORMATION + AIR TRAVEL = 50 MILLION DEAD: In an optimistic start to the General Assembly, the Global Preparedness Monitoring Board has warned that no one’s ready for the next major pandemic (think 1919’s Spanish flu), which could easily spread globally in 36 hours and kill more than 50 million people. Deutsche Welle has more.

TAKE A PEW: The Pew Research Center’s latest report on global threats (based on 2018 data) shows that climate change is still is still seen as the top concern, but cyberattacks are becoming a growing fear.

WHATEVER YOU DO, PREPARE TO WALK: If you don’t have a motorcade this week, just walk or use the subway. Do not even attempt to using group rides (like UberPool or Lyft Shared Ride), and if you do insist on using a ride-sharing app, be willing to redirect your driver away from street closures. And when you do walk, carry and ID and any U.N. or side summit credentials you’ve been issued. It’s a fortress around the main U.N. venues and nearby hotels.

DON’T FORGET: The experts at the U.N. Foundation recommend that Playbook readers carry with them phone chargers, hand sanitizer, foot blister strips and granola bars at all times. Don’t expect food and transport to be a regular part of your day, in other words.

U.N. TRIVIA: Seth Rogen and his longtime film-making buddy Evan Goldberg are developing a United Nations comedy for CBS, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

MEET ME AT THE DELEGATES’ LOUNGE: This formerly dark and smoky bar is where U.S. and Soviet ambassadors used to back-channel. Post Cold War, the lounge was redecorated under orders from the famous multilateralist queen of the Netherlands, Beatrix. The lounge is really a bar at night (in particular Fridays) with spectacular East River views, known affectionately as the U.N.’s “Seventh Committee” room.

POPEYES CHICKEN FOR THE WIN: Brazil’s President wants a new 35-year-old ambassador to handles his diplomacy in the U.S. He has relatively little international experience, but one important qualification: He is President Jair Bolsonaro’s son. Eduardo did spend a year in the U.S., however … working at Popeyes fried chicken chain in Maine. Watch him here.

ELEVATOR PITCHES: Always know what you want from the U.S. and other Security Council members: You might see their diplomats and cabinet members for two minutes only or in an elevator. You better be ready to ask on the spot.

HOT TICKET: DJ Jacques Lavoisier is spinning at the Party for Good (“From Cannes to UNGA”) on Sunday, Sept. 22, from 5-7 p.m.. Where? The Century Association, 7 W 43rd Street, New York, NY. The brains behind the party is Claudia Romo Edelman’s We Are All Human project.

Coffee Tips

Pennylane Coffee — 3-minute walk from HQ, 305 E 45th St.

Ground Central, also great for an extra-spicy ginger beer — 5-minute walk from HQ, 800 2nd Ave.

Cafe Grumpy, at the edge of the Grand Central complex — 9-minute walk from HQ, 89 E 42nd St.

Blue Bottle — 12-minute walk from HQ, 60 E 42nd St #140.

U.N. Glossary

LOST IN TRANSLATION: Welcome to the wild ride of U.N. bureaucratic self-sabotage. Here at Turtle Bay, individual U.N. agencies often have their own thesaurus and glossary services. There’s a directory of dictionaries and a general glossary.

Our favorites include:

Gs 4 through 90: These acronyms refer to various groups of U.N. member countries. As in this helpful explanation of the G6: “The G5 plus Panama.”

There’s also CONGO (Committee on Non-Government Organizations) and GUAM (a political, economic and strategic alliance uniting Georgia, Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Moldova). Sorry to actual Congo and Guam.

You can also join the Ad Hoc Working Group of the Whole of the Regular Process, UNCOPUOS (United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space) and ACABQGA, the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (General Assembly).

If that’s too simple for you, please enjoy ICPRCP. That’s the Intergovernmental Committee for Promoting the Return of Cultural Property to its Countries of Origin or its Restitution in Case of Illicit Appropriation.

A message from S&P Global: “European utilities have noted a strong rise in demand for green electricity – that is, electricity from renewable sources. An important part of the response has been the use of Guarantees of Origin (GOs) – tradable tags that certify the provenance of power supply, down to quite specific details of the generation technology involved and the geographic location. Read more essential intelligence on climate risk from S&P Global.

Bored This Weekend?

Blink-182 teams up with the rapper Lil Wayne at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn tonight, and there’s a rare screening of the 1959 film “Porgy and Bess” at Lincoln Center.

Click here for more night-life listings. The New Yorker offers recent restaurant reviews.

On the Calendar

HANDY GUIDES: You can find more than 200 events in this guide compiled by Global Health Strategies; the official summit calendar here; check out U.N. Global Compact events here; or check out the Climate Week NYC events program. The biggest business event will be the Bloomberg Global Business Forum on the theme of “Restoring Global Stability” next Wednesday September 25.

TODAY

Climate change: The first of two global climate strikes kicks off today, starting in Foley Square, Manhattan. The event is built off the back of teenagers around the world saying they’re afraid of climate change and sick of the relative inaction from their parents and grandparents. Follow it here, starring the Swedish activist Greta Thurnberg.

Central and Eastern Europe: Don’t forget the GLOBSEC Dinner at the Bohemian National Hall on the state of affairs in Central and Eastern Europe. VIPs attending include President of Slovakia Zuzana Čaputová; the next IMF chief and current World Bank CEO Kristalina Georgieva; Brookings President General John Allen; publisher Steve Forbes; Council on Foreign Relations President Richard Haass; and former NATO Deputy Secretary General Sandy Vershbow.

SATURDAY

Climate change: Youth Climate Summit

Talk business: U.S.-Africa Business Forum

Climate change: United for Climate Justice, The Maxwell Hotel, 541 Lexington Avenue. Register here.

SUNDAY — DAYTIME

All day: Social Good Summit.

All day: MIT Solve: Solve Challenge Finals — an entrepreneur pitching competition for startups working to build “Healthy Cities,” 450 East 29th Street, RSVP here.

Emissions solutions: WWF and Ericsson Exponential Roadmap Breakfast: 36 Solutions to Halve Emissions by 2030. At The Official Swedish Residence - 600 Park Avenue (64th Street). Register via Eventbrite, 7:30 – 9:30 a.m.

Get healthy: World Health Organization’s “Walk the Talk: The Health for All Challenge” - 4 miles / 6 kilometers through Central Park Free. WHO Secretary General will be there, 8:30 a.m.

Banking: Launch of U.N. Principles for Responsible Banking, at U.N. HQ., 2.00 p.m.

SUNDAY — EVENING

Africa: Concordia Summit Africa reception at the Grand Hyatt.

World peace: International Peace Institute ministerial dinner, co-hosted by Luxembourg and the United Arab Emirates.

Party time: Party for Good, at the Century Association, W43rd street.

Balkan beats: EU dinner with Western Balkans countries.

Awards: There Is No Limit Foundation’s Break the Silence Awards, founded by two Guinean sisters to support girls and prevent female genital mutilation.

Ending the night: Sunday nightcap at Goals House, at Tavern on the Green.
